summary: Build a standalone browser-based xylophone app that runs locally from a single HTML file with no backend. Users interact with 11 visually distinct bars via mouse/touch or keyboard (A-S-D-F-G row) to trigger musical notes generated in real-time using the Web Audio API with percussive decay, supporting overlapping playback and instant visual feedback.

assumptions.text: The 11-note xylophone uses a standard diatonic scale (C-D-E-F-G-A-B-C-D-E-F or similar) since specific note frequencies were not provided
Users will initiate audio via a gesture (click/tap to start) to comply with browser autoplay policies, as no explicit initialization flow was specified
The keyboard mapping uses 11 consecutive keys starting with A-S-D-F-G-H-J-K-L-semicolon-apostrophe based on standard QWERTY layout
Optional features (responsive layout, themes, volume control, sequence recording) are deferred to post-MVP based on prioritization as 'could' requirements
Target browsers are modern versions supporting Web Audio API (Chrome 34+, Firefox 25+, Safari 14.1+, Edge 79+) with graceful degradation for unsupported browsers

requirementsInterpreted.text: Display 11 visually distinct xylophone bars in the interface with clear differentiation
Show instruction text beneath the xylophone explaining how to interact via click/tap or keyboard keys
Trigger unique musical notes on mouse click, touch tap, or keyboard press for each of the 11 bars
Generate all audio using Web Audio API oscillators with gain envelopes for percussive decay, without loading external audio files
Support overlapping note playback allowing multiple bars to sound simultaneously without cutting off previous notes
Provide brief visual feedback (color change, scale, or shadow effect) when a bar is activated
Deliver as a single HTML file containing all HTML, CSS, and JavaScript with zero external dependencies or network requests
Achieve audio playback latency under 50ms from user interaction to sound output

outOfScope.text: Backend server implementation, cloud hosting, or any server-side processing
Mobile native applications for iOS or Android
Advanced music composition features like sheet music notation, MIDI export, or multi-track recording
Multi-user collaboration, sharing capabilities, or social features
Integration with external music libraries, DAWs, or third-party audio services

openQuestions.text: What specific musical scale and note frequencies should the 11 bars represent (e.g., C major diatonic, pentatonic, chromatic)?
What is the expected timeline for MVP delivery and any subsequent iterations for optional features?
Who will validate that the xylophone tones sound 'realistic and pleasant' (AC-15) before release?

riskFlags.text: Browser autoplay policies may block audio initialization without explicit user gesture, requiring a 'Start' or 'Play' button
Web Audio API implementation varies across browsers, potentially affecting tone quality and requiring cross-browser testing
No objective criteria defined for 'realistic xylophone tone' quality, making acceptance subjective without stakeholder validation process
Rapid simultaneous interactions could overload audio context or exceed polyphony limits, requiring throttling or limit enforcement
